title: 106_hr3249
content: The "Artists' Contribution to American Heritage Act of 1999" allows for charitable contributions of certain items created by the taxpayer. The "Artists' Contribution to American Heritage Act of 1999" allows for charitable contributions of literary, musical, or artistic compositions with special rules for determining the fair market value of the property contributed. The "Artists' Contribution to American Heritage Act of 1999" defines a qualified artistic charitable contribution as a donation of literary, musical, artistic, or scholarly compositions created by the taxpayer at least 18 months prior to the contribution. The taxpayer must also obtain a qualified appraisal of the fair market value of the property. The taxpayer must attach a copy of the appraisal to their income tax return for the taxable year in which the contribution was made. The donee organization must be described in subsection (b)(1)(A) and use the property in a way related to its exempt purpose under section 501. The taxpayer must provide a written statement from the donee ensuring compliance with donation provisions and the appraisal must show evidence of similar property owned and used by qualifying organizations. The increase in the deduction under this section for any taxable year is limited to the taxpayer's artistic adjusted gross income and cannot be carried over to the next year. The term 'artistic adjusted gross income' refers to the portion of a taxpayer's adjusted gross income related to income from the sale or use of property created by personal efforts and income from teaching or similar activities. This definition excludes certain contributions like letters or memoranda. The amendment made by this section applies to contributions made after the enactment of this Act. Contributions made after the enactment of this Act in taxable years ending after such date.
